Situation1: The partner is grieving the sudden loss of a close family member.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Story: I could see the pain in Mia’s eyes as she sat in the waiting area, her hands trembling around a crumpled tissue. She’d lost her brother just two days ago, and I knew she needed me—her boyfriend—to be there, to hold her, to listen, to just exist beside her in her grief. But I was at work, scissors in hand, halfway through a trim for Mrs. Lee, my favorite regular. She smiled at me in the mirror, her tone gentle as she asked if I could just snip a little more off her fringe. It was a simple request, but my mind was split. I wanted to drop everything, rush to Mia, and be the comfort she needed. At the same time, I felt the weight of my professional duty: Mrs. Lee deserved my full attention and care. My heart pounded as I glanced between the two women—one needing my love, the other my skill. I felt torn, the expectations of boyfriend and hairdresser pulling me in opposite directions, and I didn’t know which part of me to honor first.
